homepage.tagline: Track your cycle, understand your body

pregnancy.title: Pregnancy Tracker
pregnancy.noDataAlertDescription: Please enter your Last Menstrual Period (LMP) or Estimated Due Date (EDD) to start tracking your pregnancy.

overviewCard.title: Pregnancy Overview
overviewCard.description: A quick look at your current pregnancy status.

weekByWeekCard.title: Week {{week}} of Pregnancy
weekByWeekCard.babyDevelopmentContent: This week, your baby is undergoing significant changes. Consult our detailed guide for more.
weekByWeekCard.momChangesContent: Your body is adapting to pregnancy. Learn about common changes and how to manage them.

trimesterGuideCard.title: Trimester Guide
trimesterGuideCard.thirdTrimesterArticle: Third Trimester: Nearing the Finish Line

symptomSummaryCard.title: Symptom Summary
symptomSummaryCard.description: A summary of your logged symptoms during pregnancy.

fertilityModeCard.title: Fertility Tracking
fertilityModeCard.description: Track your cycle and predict your fertile window.
fertilityModeCard.noPredictionDataDescription: Log at least 2 period entries to get accurate cycle predictions.

toolsCard.title: Pregnancy Tools
toolsCard.description: Helpful tools for your pregnancy journey.
toolsCard.trackWeight: Log and monitor your weight changes.
toolsCard.logAppointments: Keep track of your prenatal appointments.
toolsCard.countKicks: Count and track your baby's movements.

educationCard.title: Pregnancy Education
educationCard.description: Informative articles and guides for every stage of pregnancy.

symptomsInsightsCard.title: Symptoms & Insights
symptomsInsightsCard.description: Gain insights into your symptoms and overall health.

week8.title: 8 Weeks: Fetal Heartbeat Visible
week8.description: The baby's heart is now beating and can be seen on ultrasound.

week12.title: 12 Weeks: All Major Organs Formed
week12.description: Your baby has all major organs formed and is now called a fetus.

week20.title: 20 Weeks: Mid-Pregnancy Scan
week20.description: The anatomy scan is usually performed around this week.

week24.title: 24 Weeks: Viability
week24.description: Babies born this early have a chance of survival with intensive medical care.

week28.title: 28 Weeks: Third Trimester Begins
week28.description: You are now entering the final trimester of your pregnancy.

week37.title: 37 Weeks: Full Term
week37.description: Your baby is now considered full term and can be born at any time.

week4.title: Week 4: Implantation and Early Development
week4.description: The blastocyst implants in the uterus, and the embryonic period begins.
week4.fact1: The embryo is about the size of a poppy seed.
week4.fact2: The neural tube, which becomes the brain and spinal cord, starts to form.
week4.fact3: A primitive heart tube is forming and will soon begin to beat.

week8.title: Week 8: Major Organs Developing
week8.description: All major organs and body systems are developing, including the brain, heart, and lungs.
week8.fact1: The embryo is now about 0.5 inches long.
week8.fact2: Tiny fingers and toes are starting to form.
week8.fact3: The heartbeat can often be detected on an ultrasound.

week12.title: Week 12: Fetus Development
week12.description: The embryo is now officially a fetus. Organs and tissues continue to grow and develop.
week12.fact1: The fetus is about 2.5 inches long and weighs about 0.5 ounces.
week12.fact2: Fingers and toes are fully formed, and nails are beginning to grow.
week12.fact3: The face is well-formed with eyes, nose, and mouth.

week16.title: Week 16: Sensory Development and Movement
week16.description: Your baby is growing rapidly, and sensory development is progressing. You might feel movement!
week16.fact1: The baby is about 4.5 inches long and weighs about 3.5 ounces.
week16.fact2: The baby's eyes are sensitive to light.
week16.fact3: Kicks and movements become more noticeable.

week20.title: Week 20: Mid-Pregnancy Milestone
week20.description: You're halfway there! Your baby is growing and becoming more active.
week20.fact1: The baby is about 6.5 inches long (crown to rump) and weighs about 10 ounces.
week20.fact2: Hair and nails continue to grow.
week20.fact3: The baby is swallowing more and producing meconium.

week24.title: Week 24: Lung Development and Hearing
week24.description: The baby's lungs are developing rapidly, and hearing is becoming more acute.
week24.fact1: The baby is about 8 inches long and weighs about 1.5 pounds.
week24.fact2: The baby can hear sounds from outside the womb.
week24.fact3: The lungs are developing air sacs (alveoli).

week28.title: Week 28: Brain Development and Eye Movement
week28.description: Your baby's brain is developing quickly, and they can open their eyes.
week28.fact1: The baby is about 10 inches long and weighs about 2.5 pounds.
week28.fact2: The baby can open and close their eyes.

week32.title: Week 32: Weight Gain and Organ Maturation
week32.description: Your baby is gaining weight rapidly, and organs are continuing to mature.
week32.fact1: The baby is about 11 inches long and weighs about 3.75 pounds.
week32.fact2: The baby's bones are hardening, but the skull remains soft for birth.
week32.fact3: Most babies are in a head-down position by this week.

week36.title: Week 36: Full-Term Development
week36.description: Your baby is nearing full term, with all systems ready for life outside the womb.
week36.fact1: The baby is about 12.5 inches long and weighs about 5.75 pounds.
week36.fact2: The baby's immune system is developing through antibodies from you.
week36.fact3: The baby's head may start to drop into the pelvis (lightening).

week40.title: Week 40: Arrival Day!
week40.description: Your baby is fully developed and ready to be born!
week40.fact1: The baby is about 13.5 inches long and weighs about 7.5 pounds.
week40.fact2: The baby's skin is smooth and soft.
week40.fact3: The baby is ready for birth!

trimesterContent.first: The first trimester is a time of rapid development for your baby and many changes for you. Morning sickness, fatigue, and breast tenderness are common. Focus on healthy eating and rest.
trimesterContent.second: The second trimester is often called the 'golden period' of pregnancy. Morning sickness usually subsides, and you may feel more energetic. You'll likely start to feel your baby move.
trimesterContent.third: The third trimester brings significant growth for your baby and increasing physical demands for you. Prepare for labor and delivery, and continue to prioritize rest and nutrition.
trimesterContent.unknown: Trimester information is not available without more data.

weekDevelopment.unknown: Development information is not available for this week.

calendar.noDataYetDescription: Log your periods to see your cycle insights.

periodLogger.endLoggedFailed: Failed to log period end. Please try again.
periodLogger.loginRequired: You must be logged in to log a period.

cycleSummary.title: Cycle Summary
cycleSummary.description: A detailed overview of your recent cycle patterns.

exportData.title: Export Cycle Data
exportData.description: Download your period and symptom logs.
exportData.info: Your data will be exported in a CSV format.

shareWithDoctor.title: Share with Doctor
shareWithDoctor.description: Securely share your cycle data with your healthcare provider.

requestAnalysis.title: Request Professional Analysis
requestAnalysis.description: Request a professional analysis of your cycle data from a healthcare expert.
requestAnalysis.info: A healthcare professional will review your data and provide personalized insights. We will contact you via email once the analysis is complete.

irregularCycles.title: Irregular Cycles
irregularCycles.description: Learn what causes irregular periods and when you should consult a doctor.

hormonalHealth.title: Hormonal Health
hormonalHealth.description: Discover how your lifestyle affects your hormonal balance and cycle health.

exerciseThroughoutCycle.title: Exercise Throughout Your Cycle
exerciseThroughoutCycle.description: Learn how to optimize your workouts according to your menstrual cycle phases.

exerciseDuringPeriodHealthline.title: Exercise During Your Period: Benefits, Safety, and More

exerciseDuringPeriodVerywell.title: Should You Exercise During Your Period?

understandingPMSGeneral.title: Understanding PMS
understandingPMSGeneral.description: Explore the physical and emotional symptoms of Premenstrual Syndrome.

pmsACOG.title: Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS)
pmsACOG.source: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists

cyclePhases.title: Understanding Your Cycle Phases
cyclePhases.description: Learn about the different phases of your menstrual cycle and what happens in each.

menstrualPhase.title: Menstrual Phase
menstrualPhase.description: The start of your period, when the uterine lining sheds.

follicularPhase.title: Follicular Phase
follicularPhase.description: The time from the first day of your period to ovulation.

ovulationPhase.title: Ovulation Phase
ovulationPhase.description: When a mature egg is released from the ovary.

lutealPhase.title: Luteal Phase
lutealPhase.description: The time from ovulation until the start of your next period.

myth1.title: Myth: All cycles are 28 days.
myth1.fact: Fact: Cycle lengths vary greatly, typically from 21 to 35 days.

myth2.title: Myth: You can't get pregnant on your period.
myth2.fact: Fact: While less likely, it's possible to conceive if you have a short cycle.

myth3.title: Myth: PMS is all in your head.
myth3.fact: Fact: PMS is a real condition with physical and emotional symptoms.

ovulation.title: Ovulation
ovulation.description: The release of a mature egg from the ovary.

fsh.title: Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)
fsh.description: A hormone that stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.

estrogen.title: Estrogen
estrogen.description: A hormone responsible for the growth and development of female secondary sexual characteristics.

progesterone.title: Progesterone
progesterone.description: A hormone that prepares the uterus for pregnancy.

periodHistory.noEntries: No entries yet. Log a period to get started!
